journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: Design and analysis of a dual-mode driven parallel XY micromanipulator for micro/nanomanipulations

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Electromechanical Engineering, University of Macau, Macao SAR, PR China
2School of Mechanical Engineering and Automation, Harbin Institute of Technology Shenzhen Graduate School, Shenzhen, PR China

author-notes.corresp: Yangmin Li, School of Mechanical Engineering and Automation, Harbin Institute of Technology Shenzhen Graduate School, Shenzhen 518055, PR China. Email: ymli@umac.mo

abstract.p: This article presents a novel design of a flexure-based, piezoelectric actuated, completely decoupled, high-bandwidth, highresolution, and large stroke parallel XY micromanipulator with two amplification levers. The monolithic mechanism is featured with dual working modes, which meets different kinds of requirements in terms of high resolution and large workspace in micro/nano fields. In order to reduce the displacement loss, the modeling and analysis of bending motion of the levers are conducted; thereafter, compliance and stiffness modeling by employing the matrix method are established. Furthermore, the dynamics modeling and analysis via Lagrange equations are performed to improve the dynamic properties of the mechanism. The simulation results of finite element analysis indicate that the cross-coupling between the two axes is kept to 1.2%; meanwhile, the natural frequency of the mechanism is about 700 Hz, and the amplifier ratio is approximately 2.32. Both theoretical analysis and finite element analysis results well validate the performance of the proposed mechanism.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Nowadays, the flexure-based and piezoelectric (PZT) actuated mechanisms with ultrahigh precision are widely applied in high technological fields including biological cell microinjection,1 atomic force microscope scanner,2 micro-electromechanical system,3 and optical fiber alignment.4 The motion of a compliant mechanism is generated by either the elastic deformation of the flexure hinges (i.e. lumped compliant mechanisms) or a portion of the structures (i.e. distributed compliant mechanism).5 Compared with the conventional mechanical joints, the flexure hinges have a lot of advantages such as no backlash, no friction, vacuum compatibility, and easy to be manufactured.6 PZT is selected as the actuating device because it has nanoscale resolution, high stiffness, and fast frequency response, while its defects of hysteresis and creep effects can be compensated by adopting advanced control methods.7

The research of compliant XY micromanipulators is conducted in this article due to their promising applications in micro/nano fields. There are two basic structures for a micromanipulator in terms of serial and parallel ones. Serial mechanism type is commercially available in some companies such as the PI and Thorlabs, which is comparatively easier to design and control, while it has the defects of high inertia, low bandwidth, and cumulative errors. To overcome these flaws, a parallel mechanism type is proposed because it has advantages such as high rigidity, high load-carrying capacity, high accuracy, low inertia, and compact structure. So far, although some micromanipulators have been developed or sold in the market,8–11 the research work is still necessary to push this technology forward to a higher level. Besides, most parallel micromanipulators are always limited by the coupled motion, stress stiffening effect, low resolution, and small workspace. In the compliant mechanisms, stress stiffening effect means that the stiffness of a structure is subject to its stress state,12 which results in amplified forces and reduced motion range of the mechanism. Moreover, most mechanisms possess complicated kinematic models since the outputs of the X and Y axes are mutually coupled, which will cause the precise positioning hard to be achieved. Generally, the term ‘decoupling’ is understood as the output decoupling, while the input decoupling of the mechanism is often ignored. For a mechanism with two or more actuating devices, when it is driven by one actuator, other actuators may be suffered from the undesired loads (such as bending moments and shearing forces). If a micromanipulator without displacement amplifying mechanism, the positioning precision will be usually higher, but its workspace is limited to the strokes of the actuators. Additional amplifying mechanisms for a micromanipulator can definitely improve the manipulator's workspace, but the positioning precision will be reduced accordingly.

In order to solve the above problems, we propose a dual-mode completely decoupled compliant XY micromanipulator (CDCM) with amplification levers driven by PZT actuators in this article. Among the previous research works about compliant XY micromanipulators, double parallelogram leaf flexure hinges and compound parallelogram flexure hinges are employed in Awtar et al.10 and Li et al.11 The first mechanism is directly driven by PZT actuators without displacement amplifiers, which leads to the mechanism workspace limited to the stroke of actuators. The main advantage of the second mechanism is an integrated design of a class of displacement amplifiers with input decoupling function. However, the unfixed PZTs connected to the displacement amplifiers vibrate easily, and the mechanism always suffers from the resonance vibration of the four-limb secondary stages at low frequency, which is at the expense of high inertia, low bandwidth, and low positioning accuracy. The main contribution of this article lies in that an integrated design is proposed for a class of levers with amplified XY CDCM with dual working modes, which has broken through the traditional concept that each XY nanopositioning mechanism possesses only one working mode. Then, the contradiction between resolution and workspace is avoided, which is considered as a key issue in micro/nano applications. Moreover, it succeeds in avoiding the flaws of output and input coupling problems. Compared with the XY stage in Yong et al.8 in which the inner section based on the beam flexure is not thoroughly decoupled, the presented CDCM possesses a completely decoupling structure, which is superior to the former one in terms of control accuracy and convenience. Besides, compared with the decoupled XY stage in Awtar et al.10 the double four-bar parallelogram is employed instead of the standard double parallelogram flexure to improve the mechanism stiffness, natural frequency, and workspace. Moreover, compared with the decoupled XY stage proposed in Li et al.11 the presented mechanism possesses low cross-coupling, higher stiffness, higher bandwidth, higher accuracy, and more selectivity to meet the requirements in different levels. Furthermore, a careful comparison with the similar mechanisms in Choi et al.13 and Liaw et al.14 it is found that the current proposed XY micromanipulator possesses completely decoupled output motion without crosstalk between the two axes in theory, which will be better suited for implementing single-input and single-output control strategy.

This article is organized as follows. First, the design of the dual-mode XY CDCM is presented in ‘Design and enumeration of XY CDCM’ section, where one structure is proposed as an example for the subsequent studies. Second, modeling and analysis of the lever bending will be conducted in the next section. Third, compliance and stiffness analysis of the mechanism based on the compliance matrix method are presented. Afterwards, the dynamics modeling and analysis via Lagrange approach is conducted and validated by the finite element analysis (FEA). Finally, the conducted research work is summarized and future research direction is pointed out in ‘Conclusions’ section.

sec.title: Design and enumeration of XY CDCM
Design of a decoupled XY compliant micromanipulator
sec.p:
In compliant mechanism, an XY parallel mechanism with two translational motions can be described by the screw theory15 or the Lie groups approach.16 Generally, the mechanism structure can be classified as 4-PP,11 5R, PRRRP, RPRPR, and 2-RPa,17,18 etc., where the terms R, P, and Pa stand for the revolute, prismatic, and the parallelogram joint, respectively. In order to design a XY CDCM, a 2-PP parallel mechanism is employed due to its simple structure, as shown in Figure. 1. The decoupled structure is built based on 2-PP (P represents prismatic joint) parallel mechanism with orthometric structure and double parallelogram flexure hinges are employed as prismatic joints. Figure 1.
Scheme of the parallel XY micromanipulator.

The flexure parallel mechanisms possess high stiffness and high natural frequencies, which will bring many advantages including high precision and good repeatability to perform the tasks. Three P joints without stiffening and buckling are shown in Figure. 2. The first type is the conventional parallelogram, which possesses a simple structure, while the cross-coupling will be generated when an external force is loaded. To solve this problem, the double parallelogram and the double four-bar parallelogram are good choices.19 The double parallelogram can be taken as a serial connection of two parallelogram joints, the secondary stage is mobile and the four limbs have the consistent length so that the cross-coupling will be compensated when the external force is loaded. Its motion range is large; however, the asymmetric structure will result in nonuniform thermal expansion, which will reduce positioning precision in practical applications. According to the pseudo-rigid-body (PRB) model, the equivalent stiffness of this joint can be calculated as follows20 (1)K1=2Kθ/λ1 2 where Kθ is the stiffness value related to the geometric parameters of the flexure hinge, and λ1 the distance between two adjacent hinges of the double parallelograms. Figure 2.
Typical types of prismatic flexure hinges.

As shown in Figure 3(a), it can be calculated as follows21 (2)Kθ=2Ewt2.59πr0.5 where E represents the Young's modulus, w, t, and r the thickness, minimum thickness, and circle radius of circular flexure hinge, respectively. The double four-bar parallelograms can be considered as a parallel connection of two joints of parallelograms. Its equivalent stiffness can be calculated as (3)K2=8Kθ/λ2 2 where λ2 is the distance between two adjacent hinges of the double four-bar parallelograms. From equations (1) and (3), it is observed that the double four-bar joints perform better than the double-parallelogram joints in terms of stiffness when identical links and hinges are used. Moreover, the right circular flexure hinge is adopted since its displacement accuracy is better than the others. (i.e. the center of flexure is displaced much smaller than the other types).22 Figure 3.
Flexure hinges: (a) circular flexure hinges, (b) coordinate frame, (c) beam flexure hinge, and (d) equivalent hinge model.

Based on the above analysis, a conceptual design of a XY CDCM with the double-parallelogram flexure joints is proposed in Figure 4(a) and (b). As for the structure shown in Figure 4(a), if we set the identical length to the limbs, the ideal outputs of XY motions of the mobile platform without cross-coupling will be obtained once they are driven by two linear PZT actuators which are mounted by rigid connections at the interfaces. Furthermore, since the double four-bar flexure hinges possess both high compliance in its working direction and high stiffness in the transverse direction, the actuators are protected from the transverse loads or bending moments. This is one of the reasons why input decoupling is expected in a XY micromanipulator. But even so, the improvements will be achieved by adopting mirror-symmetric structure as shown in Figure 4(b), which makes the mechanism possess higher stiffness and higher positioning accuracy in-plane and out-of-plane. Moreover, it is more robust against manufacturing tolerances, temperature disturbances, and assembly errors.19 Figure 4.
Conceptual designs of XY CDCM. CDCM: completely decoupled complaint micromanipulator.

sec.title: A dual-mode XY CDCM design with amplification levers
sec.p: As mentioned, during designing XY micro/nanopositioning mechanism with PZT actuators, the contradiction between resolution and workspace has become a bottleneck which restricts the development and application. Besides, PZT has been widely used as the actuator due to its major advantages of large blocking force, high stiffness, high resolution, fast response, and compact size. However, the main drawback of small stroke has limited the motion scope of the actuated mechanism. As we know, additional displacement amplifiers will helpfully improve the workspace of the mechanisms, but the positioning precision will be reduced accordingly.

Even so, in order to design a nanopositioning mechanism with compact structure and to fully exploit the large blocking force and stiffness of the PZT, several types of amplifiers have been proposed and applied.23,24 However, these amplifiers possess a relative low lateral stiffness, which are not sufficient to bear any external loads.

Based on the above analysis, we propose a novel dual-mode driven parallel XY micromanipulator with amplification levers. As shown in Figure 5, this mechanism consists of two main parts: (a) the outer one consists of two amplification levers with circular flexure hinges and (b) the inner one consists of a stage based on 4-PP flexure structure moving in X- and Y-axes, respectively. Figure 5.
The proposed parallel XY CDCM driven by dual mode. CDCM: completely decoupled complaint micromanipulator and PZT: piezoelectric. The mechanism consists of the outer and the inner parts.

sec.title: The advantages of dual mode
sec.p:
As shown in Figure 5, this mechanism possesses two working modes, which can meet the requirements in different levels. On one hand, if a positioning with large motion scope is needed, but lower requirements in accuracy, we can take advantage of the amplification levers, which have integrated into each axis of the stage to amplify the displacement of the PZT actuators. The amplified motions are transferred to the inner part to drive the mobile platform. As shown in Figure 6, the motion range of the PZT actuator is amplified by the lever, but the motion accuracy of the mechanism is reduced accordingly, which can be described as follows (4)Aoi=DlevDpzt
(5)Rout=AoiRpzt where Aoi denotes the displacement amplification ratio of the levers, Dlev and Dpzt, respectively, the output displacement of the lever tip and the output displacement of the PZT actuators, and Rout and Rpzt, respectively, the motion resolution (accuracy) of the lever tip and the PZT. Figure 6.
The schematic diagram of the amplification lever. PZT: piezoelectric.

On the other hand, if a positioning with high accuracy is needed, but lower requirements in terms of motion scope, we can directly drive the actuators on the lever tip, which makes the mechanism motion resolution identical to the resolution of the PZT actuators since the driving forces are transferred to the inner part to directly move the mobile platform without any amplifications.

As shown in Figure 5, circular flexure hinges are employed in the design of the amplification levers. As mentioned above, they can provide more accurate rotational motions, i.e. the center of deflection can be estimated to be at the center of the circular flexure.8,21 Besides, circular flexure hinges are employed to avoid the parasitic rotational motion in Z-axis, since the parasitic rotational motion always occurs along with the twisting resonant modes (about the X- and Y-axes) at low frequencies. Figure 7 shows the comparisons between the two twisting resonant modes (by ANSYS) of the two amplification levers employing beam and circular flexure hinges, respectively. The beam and circular flexure hinges are assigned with the same length (Lb = 2r) and the same minimum thickness (t) for comparison. The simulation results indicate that the twisting resonant mode occurs at approximately 948 Hz for the amplification levels with circular flexure hinges, which is higher than 831 Hz for the levels with beam flexure hinges (the translational resonance frequency is approximately 700 Hz). Therefore, circular flexure hinges are chosen for the design of the amplification levers to avoid the trouble of parasitic motion. The amplification ratio of the lever is estimated approximately to be 2.32. Figure 7.
Twisting resonant modes with different amplification levers: (a) with circular flexure hinge, the twisting mode occurs at 948 Hz and (b) with beam flexure hinge, the twisting mode occurs at 832 Hz.

sec.title: Design considerations
sec.p:
Our goal is to design a completely decoupled parallel XY micromanipulator with high bandwidth, high resolution, and large stroke. Table 1 presents the structural and material parameters of the proposed mechanism, where l1 and l2 are the lengths between the two adjacent hinges in the kinematic chains, E the Young's modulus, σ the Yield strength, υ the Poisson's ratio, and ρ the density of the material. To improve the bandwidth, the design of the mechanism must be compact and rigid25 to obtain a higher natural frequency. From formulae (2) and (3), the smaller size of the levers and hinges will reduce the overall X- and Y-axes motion range of the mechanism. Moreover, to increase the natural frequency of the mechanism, a material with high Young's modulus of elasticity E to low density ratio ρ is preferred since a stiff and light material (high E and low ρ) will increase the stiffness and bandwidth of the stage. Based on the analysis above, aluminum alloy 7075 (a relatively high value of E/ρ) is selected as the fabricated material. Furthermore, the mechanism stiffness (Ks) should be carefully considered, since the maximum motion range of the PZT actuator is constrained to the Ks as follows26 (6)ΔL=KaKa+KsΔL0 where ΔL is the motion scope of a PZT with external load, ΔL0 the nominal stroke of a PZT without external load, Ka the natural stiffness of the PZT actuator, and Ks the structural stiffness of a mechanism. Table 1.
Parameters of the XY CDCM.
Structural parameters (mm)
r t h w l1 l2
2.5 0.5 5.5 8 8.5 8.5
ha tp
30 1
Material parameters
E σ υ ρ
71.7 GPa 503 MPa 0.33 2.81 × 103 kg/m3
CDCM: Completely decoupled complaint micromanipulator.

In order to increase the natural frequency of a nanopositioning mechanism, a high value of Ks is required; however, this will result in a decreased maximum displacement of a PZT. To reach an acceptable compromise, generally, Ks is chosen to be approximately 20% of the value of Ka, thus a mechanism with higher natural frequency without loss too much of its motion scope can be obtained once the PZT actuators with higher stiffness are selected.

sec.title: Modeling and analysis of deflection of the levers
Modeling of the levers
sec.p: The displacement amplification ratio of the nanopositioning mechanism will be reduced if there is a ‘displacement loss’ effect at the input end of the lever. This ‘lost displacement’ is caused by the integration of the bending of the lever arm and the stretching of the flexure hinges, etc.27 To overcome this problem, the levers will be modeled and analyzed in this design.

A diagram of the lever mechanism employed in this analysis is displayed in Figure 8(a). The ideal amplification ratio is L/a, where a and b are the lengths of the input and output lever arms, respectively. L is the total length of the lever: L= a + b, the pivot is modeled as an elastic hinge. The gravity factor is not considered in this model since the nanopositioning mechanism is planar and horizontally placed. According to the relationship between the forces and the moments, the equilibrium equations can be derived as follows28 (7)F-f1-f2=0
(8)M1-Fa+f2L=0 where F is the driving force, f1 the reaction force at the pivot of the lever, f2 the reaction force at the lever tip, and M1 the moment applied at the pivot of the lever. As shown in Figure 8(b), let the deflection at x = L be δm, thus f2 = Ksδm. Moreover, the relationship between δm and the average bending angle θ is δm = Ltan θ = Lθ, then the moment at the pivot can be derived as follows (9)M1=KpδmL where Kp denotes the stiffness of the lever pivot hinge. Considering the different values of x, two bending moment equations are derived as follows Figure 8.
The lever models: (a) lever bearing and (b) lever bending.

when 0 ≤ x ≤ a, then (10)EIω··=M1-f1x when a ≤ x ≤ L, then (11)EIω··=M1-f1x+F(x-a) where E is the Young's modulus, I the moment of inertia of the cross section, ω the deflection of the lever, and x the coordinate value of any point on the lever. The ‘displacement loss’ happens when the coordinate value is set at the range of a ≤ x ≤ L. Making an integral transformation on both sides of equation (11), the following equation can be derived (12)EIω=M12x2-f16x3+F6(x-a)3+c1x

Solving the above equations by the boundary condition (x = L, ω = δm), the results are as follows (13)M1=KpFaKsL1Kp/KsL+L
(14)c1=1L (EIδm-M12L2+f16L3-F6b3 )
(15)θ=M1Kp=FaKsL1Kp/KsL+L=FaKp+KsL2

Equation (15) provides the solution for the average bending angle of the lever. It reveals that the average bending angle is inverse to the value of Kp when the values of F, a, Ks, and L are constants. Therefore, the ‘displacement loss’ can be reduced by increasing the stiffness of the lever arm and the nominal stiffness of the pivot hinges.

sec.title: Model verification with FEA
sec.p:
For the purpose of assessing the amplification ratio influenced by the stiffness of pivot hinges and the lever arm, the established models are validated by the ANSYS software. As shown in Figure 9, the finite element model is built based on the designed geometrical structure, where the 20-node element SOLID 186 is adopted to mesh the solid model and a force of 50 N is loaded at the X-axis actuation point. In order to achieve the best performance, a number of design iterations have been conducted until the desired results are obtained. The static analysis results are picked out for comparison, which are shown, respectively, in Figure 9(a) and (b). In this multicolor figure, the output displacement value of each nodal point of the CDCM is displayed. The red color represents the maximum displacement and blue color the minimum displacement. In order to vividly describe the phenomenon of lever bending, the deformations have been exaggeratedly displayed by setting the scale factor to 500. Where the symbol tp denotes the minimum thickness of the lever pivot hinges and ha the maximum width of the levers. It is observed that the amplification ratios are 1.40 and 2.32 accordingly, when tp and ha are set to the pairs of 0.5 and 15 mm, or 1 and 30 mm, respectively. It can be identified that the effect of lever bending is the major factor which has reduced the amplifier ratios of the levers, while this effect has been suppressed by increasing the stiffness of the levers and the pivot hinges. Figure 9.
The lever bending results with different dimensions.

sec.title: Compliance and stiffness analysis based on matrix method
sec.p: There are various approaches to model a compliant mechanism, among which the most commonly used one is PRB method. However, PRB method cannot be employed for accurate and complete compliance/stiffness analysis since it only considers the compliance of the hinges in their working directions. Besides, nonlinear modeling approach in terms of deformation of each component of the mechanism can be performed, while modeling it fully is not an easy job since numerous integral operations should be conducted.11 Therefore, the lumped model of a flexure with the consideration of 6-D (or concerned) compliance in space can be effectively derived by the compliance matrix method under the assumption of Hooke's law, since the matrix operations can be efficiently conducted.29,30 In this section, the matrix-based compliance and stiffness modeling as well as verification are carried out on the proposed XY CDCM.

sec.title: Compliance of kinematic chain
sec.p:
To obtain the compliance of the whole mechanism, the local compliance of all the flexures should be transformed to a specified point. Then, the compliance of all the elements connected in serial and parallel should be added to obtain the integrated compliance.31 Taking the kinematic chain A, shown in Figure 10, for illustration, link g is the fixed base and link o the motion stage. Then, the compliance of chain a in coordinate A-xy will be derived as (16)Ca A=C1 A+C2 A=T1 AC1(T1 A)T+T2 AC2(T2 A)T where Ci A stands for the compliance of flexure hinge i in coordinate A-xy, Ci the compliance of flexure hinge i in its local coordinate and Ti A the compliance transformation matrix from the local coordinate of flexure hinge i to coordinate A-xy. As shown in Figure 3(d), flexure hinges are considered to have three degrees of freedom, therefore a simplified 3 × 3 compliance matrix model for each flexure hinge element is employed instead of a full 6 × 6 compliance matrix model.11 Once an external force F¯=[ fx fy mz]T is loaded on the point Oi of the flexure hinge, as described in Figure 3(b), the displacement D=[dx dy θz]T of Oi with respect to its local coordinate can be expressed as follows (17)D¯=[c10-c30c50-c30c7]F¯=COiF¯ where COi is the compliance matrix which describes the compliance of the hinge expressed in its local coordinate, the compliance factors ci are derived by the corresponding formula.29 Figure 10.
Kinematic chain A of the XY CDCM. CDCM: completely decoupled complaint micromanipulator.

Flexures b and a are symmetric with respect to Y-axis; hence, the compliance of flexure b in coordinate A-xy can be obtained by rotating the compliance of flexure a by 180° around the Y-axis (18)Cb A=R¯y(π)Ca A(R¯y(π))T where R¯y(π) is the rotation matrix of the compliance. According to the top-down symmetric property, the compliances of flexures c and d in coordinate A-xy are obtained as follows (19)Cc A=R¯x(-π)Ca A(R¯x(-π))T
(20)Cd A=R¯x(-π)Cb A(R¯x(-π))T

Flexures a, b, c, and d are connected to the mobile platform o in parallel; therefore, the compliance of this transverse P joint in coordinate A-xy is derived as (21)Ctran A=((Ca A)-1+(Cb A)-1+(Cc A)-1+(Cd A)-1)-1
In the same way, the compliance of the vertical P joint in coordinate A-xy can be derived as (22)Cvert A=((Cm A)-1+(Cn A)-1+(Cp A)-1+(Cs A)-1)-1

sec.title: Output compliance of the XY CDCM
sec.p: The output compliance is defined as the compliance matrix related to the output displacements of the mobile platform and the external forces/moments loaded on it.

Because the parallel mechanism behaves like the double symmetric property, only one kinematic chain is picked out for illustration. As shown in Figure 10, the chain is constructed by serial connections of transverse and vertical P joints. Hence, the compliance of the whole chain A in coordinate A-xy is obtained by adding the compliances of the two P joints (23)CA=Cvert A+Ctran A
Making a compliance transformation from coordinate A-xy to the target coordinate O-xy (24)CA O=TA OCA(TA O)T

The compliance matrices of kinematic chains B, C, and D can be derived by rotating the compliance of chain A in coordinate O-xy by −90°, −180° and −270° around Z-axis, respectively (25)CB O=R¯z(-π/2)CA O(R¯z(-π/2))T
(26)CC O=R¯z(-π)CA O(R¯z(-π))T
(27)CD O=R¯z(-3π/2)CA O(R¯z(-3π/2))T
Therefore, the output compliance of the whole parallel mechanism in coordinate O-xy will be calculated as (28)Cout=((CA O)-1+(CB O)-1+(CC O)-1+(CD O)-1)-1

sec.title: Input stiffness of the XY CDCM
sec.p:
The input stiffness is defined as the stiffness related to the input displacements and the input forces at the actuation point. Theoretically, the XY CDCM possesses the identical value of input stiffness in X- and Y-axes for its symmetric structure. To derive the input stiffness in Y-axis, the compliance model of the mechanism is established and displayed in Figure 11. The compliances of kinematic chains B, C, and D are transferred from coordinate O-xy to E-xy; meanwhile, the compliances of the transverse and the vertical P joints in chain A are transferred from coordinate A-xy to coordinate E-xy. To calculate the compliance of the actuation point E, chains B, C, and D are considered to be connected in parallel at point O. Then, the integral compliance of these three chains is obtained as (29)CBCD E=(TO E)((CB O)-1+(CC O)-1+(CD O)-1)-1(TO E)T
Figure 11.
Compliance model of the XY CDCM. CDCM: completely decoupled complaint micromanipulator.
These three chains are connected to the transverse P joint in series, thus the integral compliance of the chains B, C, D with transverse P joint is calculated as (30)Crest E=CBCD E+TA ECtran A(TA E)T

The vertical P joint is connected in parallel to the rest of the part including the chains B, C, and D and the transverse P joint at point E. Hence, the compliance of point E will be derived as follows (31)CE=((Crest E)-1+(Cvert E)-1)-1
Finally, the input stiffness of the whole mechanism is obtained as follows (32)Kin=1/CE(2,2)

sec.title: Model validation with FEA
sec.p:
As indicated in equations (28) and (32), the derived models for calculating the output compliance, input stiffness of the XY CDCM are programmed via MATLAB software, which are validated by FEA static analysis (by ANSYS software). A 3-D finite element model is established with the 20-node element SOLID186. Moreover, the smart mesh method is employed to improve the computational accuracy and efficiency. After creating the mesh model, a zero displacement constraint is applied on the surfaces of the model edge to immobilize the mechanism. In order to completely evaluate the mechanism performance, a series of pressures (e.g. 1,041,666 N/m2, 100 N) are loaded at the input end of the amplification lever under the working modes 1 and 2, respectively, (Figure 5). Then, the corresponding results are obtained which are displayed, respectively, in Tables 2 and 3. It reveals that the relationship between the force and the displacement is nearly linear, while the output compliances of modes 1 and 2 are 0.21 and 0.33 µm/N (1 µm = 10−6 m), respectively, which are close to the theoretical values (the deviations is kept to 6.1%). Besides, the input stiffness of modes 1 and 2 are 4.86 and 3.45 N/µm, respectively, which are close to the theoretical values (the deviations is less than 6.5%). All the tests show that the input stiffness is less than the minimum stiffness of PZT actuators (14∼208 N/µm ± 20%), which demonstrates that there is no stress stiffening trouble in this mechanism and it can be normally driven by the PZT actuators. Besides, the cross-axis displacements between the X- and Y-axes are less than 0.24 µm (the error is kept to 1.2%), as well as the parasitic rotational motion around the Z-axis is 1.33 µrad, which has further confirmed that this mechanism is well decoupled. Table 2.
The performance parameters of mode 1.
Items Output compliance (µm/N) Input stiffness (N/µm) Natural frequency, X (Hz) Natural frequency, Y (Hz)
Theory model 0.22 4.55 647.02 647.02
FEA 0.21 4.86 688.72 714.60
Deviation (%) 4.55 6.38 6.06 9.46
FEA: finite element analysis.
Table 3.
The performance parameters of mode 2.
Items Output compliance (µm/N) Input stiffness (N/µm) Natural frequency, X (Hz) Natural frequency, Y (Hz)
Theroy model 0.31 3.23 647.02 647.02
FEA 0.33 3.45 688.72 714.60
Deviation (%) 6.06 6.38 6.06 9.46
FEA: finite element analysis.

sec.title: Dynamics modeling
sec.p: The natural frequencies of the CDCM can be obtained using Lagrange's equation. The input displacement variables G = [dx, dy]T are chosen as the generalized coordinates, where dx is the input displacement in X-axis and dy the input displacement in Y-axis, then the kinetic and potential energies (T and V) of the XY CDCM are described by the generalized coordinates. It is assumed that the potential energies are induced by elastic deformations of flexure hinges and the kinetic energies by the movement of flexure hinges. The gravity factor is not taken into account since the mechanism will be horizontally placed.

As shown in Figure 5, the potential energy of the whole mechanism is calculated as follows (33)V=12Kinxdx 2+12Kinydy 2 where Kinx and Kiny are the values of input stiffness in X- and Y-axes, respectively. The kinetic energy of chain A will be calculated as (34)TA=12mT (12d·x )2+12mT (12d·y )2+12 (112 )mTl1 2 (d·xl1 ) +12mV (12d·y )2+12mg (d·y )2+12 (112 )mVl2 2 (d·yl2 )2 where (35)mT=ma+mb+mc+md
(36)mV=mm+mn+ms+mp where mT and mV represent the total mass in terms of hinges in transverse and vertical directions, respectively, and ma, mb, mc, md, mm, mn, ms, and mp the mass of the related flexure hinges, as shown in Figure 10. According to the double symmetric property, the kinetic energies of the other three chains B, C, and D of this mechanism will be obtained as (37)TB=12mT (12d·y )2+12mT (12d·x )2 +12 (112 )mTl1 2 (d·yl1 )+12mV (12d·x )2 +12mg (d·x )2+12 (112 )mVl2 2 (d·xl2 )2
(38)TC=TA
(39)TD=TB

The kinetic energy of the mobile platform is derived as follows (40)TO=12mo(d·x)2+12mo(d·y)2 where mo is the mass of the mobile platform. Then, the kinetic energy of the whole mechanism will be derived as: (41)T=TA+TB+TC+TD+TO= (43mT+mg+13mV+12mo ) (d·x )2 + (43mT+mg+13mV+12mo ) (d·y )2

Substituting T and V into the Lagrange's equation as follows (42)ddt∂T∂G·i-∂T∂Gi+∂V∂Gi=Fi where Fi (i = 1, 2) is the ith actuation force. Then, the following dynamics equation for undamped free vibration of the mechanism is obtained: (43)MG+KG=0 where the mass matrix M and the stiffness matrix K are M=diag {83mT+2mg+23mV+mo }2×2 , K = diag{Kin}2×2.

According to the vibration theory,8 the modal equation describing the vibration of the system can be obtained as (44)(K-Mξi 2)ϕi=0 where ξi and φi are the eigenvalue and eigenvector relevant to the ith mode shape of the mechanism.
Solving the characteristic equation, then (45)|K-Mξi 2|=0
The natural frequency of the i-axis will be calculated as (46)fi=12πK(i,i)M(i,i)

Obviously, it reveals that the larger input stiffness will generate the higher natural frequency when the mass remains constant, which is identical to the previous findings in ‘Design and enumeration of XY CDCM’ section.

sec.title: Modeling verification with FEA
sec.p:
The modal analysis via ANSYS is carried out to verify the dynamic equation, where the 20-node element SOLID 186 and the smart mesh method are adopted to mesh the solid model with improved computational accuracy. Although only the first and second natural frequencies are the most important for the design and control purposes, the first eight mode shapes are extracted and exaggeratedly displayed in Figure 12. As shown in this multicolor figure, the relative displacement values of the different modes are displayed, where red color represents the maximum displacement and blue color the minimum displacement. It shows that the two translational vibrations of the stage occur at the first and second modes, and the natural frequency is 688.716 and 714.603 Hz, respectively. As given in Tables 2 and 3, the deviations between the theoretical model and the FEA results are less than 10%, which validate the rationality of the derived models. Moreover, the FEA results show that the first two translational frequencies are almost identical, which confirms that the XY CDCM possesses similar dynamic behavior in the two motion axes. Furthermore, it is observed that the two twisting resonances of the amplification levers occur at the modes (3 and 4), while these frequencies are much higher than the translational motion frequencies. Besides, the twisting rotational resonance frequency and the other parasitic motion resonance frequencies are shown at the modes (5–8), which reveal that the undesired motions of this mechanism can be successfully avoided once the frequency is set below 948 Hz. Figure 12.
The first eight mode shapes of the XY CDCM. CDCM: completely decoupled complaint micromanipulator.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This article presents a conceptual design of a completely decoupled compliant parallel XY micromanipulator driven by PZT actuators. The mechanism possesses two modified amplification levers with dual working modes, which has avoided the contradiction between resolution and workspace in micro/nano manipulations. Moreover, it possesses advantages such as high bandwidth, large motion scope, input decoupling, and output decoupling. In order to overcome the problem of ‘displacement loss’ caused by the combination of the lever bending and the flexure hinge stretching, the modeling and analysis of deflection of levers are conducted. After a series of modeling and analysis in terms of compliance, stiffness, and dynamics, we have performed FEA via ANSYS software to validate the established models and evaluate the performance of the mechanism. The simulation results indicate that the proposed XY CDCM possesses an ideal property for micro/nanoapplications. Moreover, although only the circular flexure hinge is employed in this design, some other types of flexure hinges can also be tried. To overcome the problem of ‘displacement loss’, a more detailed modeling and verification will be conducted in our further work.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research was supported in part by National Natural Science Foundation of China under grant no. 61128008, Macao Science and Technology Development Fund under grant no. 016/2008/A1, Research Committee of University of Macau under grant no. MYRG203(Y1-L4)-FST11-LYM, and the State Key Laboratory of Industrial Control Technology Fund of Zhejiang University under grant no. ICT1104.
